G.L. c. 209C \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this Complaint pursuant to G.L. c. 209C § 20 and G.L. c. 208 § 28, as this matter concerns the custody and parenting time of a minor child and there has been a material change in circumstances necessitating modification of the most recent custody order issued by this Court on May 15, 2019.

G.L. c. 208 \u00a7 28.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208 § 28, child custody orders may be modified when a material and substantial change in circumstances makes modification necessary to serve the best interests of the child.

*Blake v. Blake*, 65 Mass. App. Ct. 1029.proposition: Massachusetts courts consistently hold that the best interests of the child are paramount in custody matters.

*Custody of Zia*, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237,.proposition: Massachusetts courts consistently hold that the best interests of the child are paramount in custody matters.
*Custody of Zia*, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237,.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that custody orders under G.L. c. 209C are made based on a determination of the child’s best interests, cites prior Massachusetts authority for this standard, and applies that standard throughout its analysis of which parent should have custody. While the case does not use the word “paramount,” it clearly affirms that the governing standard in Massachusetts custody matters is the best interests of the child, consistent with the proposition.
*Custody of Zia*, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237,.relevant_excerpt: “‘[C]ustody orders and judgments [including those under G. L. c. 209C] are made on the basis of a determination of the best interests of the child . . . .’ R. H. v. B. F., 39 Mass. App. Ct. at 39. See Bak v. Bak, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 616 (1987); Carr v. Carr, 44 Mass. App. Ct. at 925; Freedman v. Freedman, 49 Mass. App. Ct. 519, 522 (2000), and a judge may consider any factors found pertinent to those interests in the circumstances of the dispute.”}

*Bukow v. Bukow*, 55 Mass. App. Ct. 833.proposition: A material change in circumstances can include changes in a parent’s living situation, a child’s developmental needs, and the logistics of existing visitation arrangements.
*Bukow v. Bukow*, 55 Mass. App. Ct. 833.support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt concerns land registration, negligence, and issue preclusion related to loss of property rights and the land registration assurance fund. It does not address family law, child custody, visitation, or what constitutes a material change in circumstances regarding parenting arrangements. Therefore, it cannot be authority for the proposition about changes in a parent’s living situation, a child’s developmental needs, or visitation logistics as material changes in circumstances.
*Bukow v. Bukow*, 55 Mass. App. Ct. 833.relevant_excerpt: “Absence of negligence on Putignano’s part, or her predecessors in title, in the loss of her property interest, if any, is a condition of such rights as she may have against the Treasurer under the statute. For that reason her amended complaint alleges she and her predecessors ‘were without negligence in the course of the proceedings which resulted in the registration by another person as the owner of the subject parcel of real estate.’”

*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.proposition: A material change in circumstances can include changes in a parent’s living situation, a child’s developmental needs, and the logistics of existing visitation arrangements.
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses what constitutes a material change in circumstances for modifying alimony and child support, but only in terms of financial changes (income, earning capacity, and assets) and, tangentially, second-family expenses. It does not address changes in a parent’s living situation, a child’s developmental needs, or visitation logistics as potential material changes. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. … The needs of the children, the financial status of the support provider, and the station in life of the respective parties must all be considered. … A substantial and permanent decrease in the income of the support provider is one of the material circumstances to be considered in a request for reduction of a support award.”

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: Courts have recognized that as children grow older, custody arrangements may need to evolve to accommodate the child’s changing developmental, educational, and emotional needs.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on standards for removal of children from the jurisdiction and the relationship between the custodial parent’s wellbeing and the child’s best interests. While it mentions the child’s emotional, physical, and developmental needs, it does so in the context of evaluating a proposed international move at a single point in time, not in recognizing that custody arrangements should evolve as children grow older. There is no discussion of modifying custody based on the child’s changing developmental stage or age-related needs over time.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Courts have recognized that as children grow older, custody arrangements may need to evolve to accommodate the child’s changing developmental, educational, and emotional needs.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames the best-interests analysis as grounded in the "particular needs and circumstances of the individual child" and then applies that to the older child’s current developmental, educational, and emotional situation, including his ADHD, socialization issues, and need for continuity in a supportive school environment. While the case is about relocation rather than a generic custody-modification scenario, the court recognizes that custody/placement decisions must respond to the child’s evolving developmental and educational needs as he grows older, supporting the general proposition. The support is inferential rather than in a broad doctrinal statement, so confidence is medium.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’ … The Chelmsford school district has initiated a student accommodation plan for the child, and his middle school has established an ‘active and effective support system for him.’ … The judge concluded that, in light of the disruptions to his developmental process that would be occasioned by the challenges of a new home, school, and sibling, and reduction in the time spent with the father, the move to New Hampshire would be ‘detrimental’ to the older child’s socialization and education.”

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Stability and meaningful relationships with both parents are critical components of a child’s best interests.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on relocation and custody modification standards (material change in circumstances, the Yannas ‘real advantage’ test, and the tie between the custodial parent’s well‑being and the child’s best interests). While it acknowledges the importance of the child’s relationships with each parent and extended family, it does not articulate a general legal principle that “stability and meaningful relationships with both parents are critical components” of best interests. Its concern is more specifically with preserving the child’s relationship with the primary custodial parent and properly applying relocation doctrine, rather than elevating equal relationships with both parents as a critical component of best interests.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Caleb was found to be a ‘physically and emotionally healthy’ boy whose ‘frequent, continuing and equal interaction . . . with each parent is most beneficial to him.’ ‘Both parents serve as equally important guides for this child’s continued healthy development.’ ‘The Court finds the minor child’s life is enriched by each parent’s equal participation in his upbringing.’ These findings would not support a decision denying removal.”

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.proposition: Stability and meaningful relationships with both parents are critical components of a child’s best interests.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly recognizes that children are entitled to the love, companionship, and concern of both parents and that frequent and continuing contact with both is valued by the law. While the court ultimately rejects joint custody due to high parental conflict, its discussion of best interests clearly treats maintaining meaningful relationships with both parents and minimizing disruption to the children’s lives as important components of their welfare. Thus, the case supports the cited proposition, even though it balances that against the need for stability with the primary caretaker.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.relevant_excerpt: “The husband does argue, however, that it is most often preferred that both parents participate in the child rearing process… We agree with the precept that ‘the law sees a value in “frequent and continuing contact” of the child[ren] with both… parents.’… Children are entitled to the love, companionship and concern of both parents, and they usually are better off if the parents can agree to share in the responsibility of their rearing as well as in physical custody.”
